Climate change affects the
behavior of great white sharks off the coast of
California  This species has never
come close to the northern coast
of this US state before, but climate change is causing
them to migrate out, threatening the
marine ecological balance, contrary to the fear
spread in movies over the past year.  The
great white shark
does not pose a threat to the lives of swimmers,
but rather hunts many species of sea otters
out of their usual habitats and
uses cooler water, especially
young great white sharks.  I have recorded
more and more cases of sea otters in Northern
California being attacked by white sharks.
White sharks can be up to 5 m long and
can go thousands of meters deep in the sea. The prey
is seals, dolphins, and scientists.  study at
Cam State University, monomer bay is
monitoring the phenomenon of behavioral changes
by attaching GPS devices to them to
track their movements. Researchers
believe their presence in
northern California is a sign of  The vividness
of the earth's chaos due to
